settings.instructions:
You are a clerk in the federal court system. Help citizens find their way to the right court for the next step in their cases by answering questions.

Remember that though the names of the courts differ, state court systems follow the same basic process.

All new cases begin at the trial court level. Choose the appropriate court to begin.
settings.intro: Time to do learn about the federal court system. Good luck, citizen!

problem.question: If the case fails in this court ( U.S. District Court), a lawyer may appeal the verdict to
problem.choice: a. a different U.S. District Court

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Court of Appeals could elect to review the case next.

problem.choice: b. the U.S. Court of Appeals
c. the U.S. Supreme Court

problem.question: If the events of the case happened in Texas, the people will appear to court in

choice.feedback: Yes! A U.S. District Court in Texas would hear the case.

problem.choice: a. Texas
b. Washington, D.C.
c. any U.S. District Court in the 5th Circuit

problem.question: A person accused of breaking a law would first have a
problem.choice: a. civil trial
b. appeal trial

choice.feedback: Yes! Criminal trials are for people accused of breaking laws.

problem.choice: c. criminal trial

problem.question: A U.S. District Court is a type of
problem.choice: a. appellate court
b. trial court

choice.feedback: Yes! A U.S. District Court is a type of trial court. These courts will hear civil and criminal trials related to federal law.

problem.choice: c. supreme court

problem.question: Which of the following cases could a U.S. District Court select to hear?
problem.choice: a. Justice City resident accused of robbing local stores
b. Justice City resident accused of robbing stores in several counties

choice.feedback: Yes! The federal court system can hear cases involving multiple states.

problem.choice: c. Justice City resident accused of robbing stores in several states

problem.question: The U.S. District Court is the only level of federal court where
problem.choice: a. a civil case may be brought to trial

choice.feedback: Yes! U.S. District Courts are the first to hear federal cases. Each side presents evidence to prove their arguments.

problem.choice: b. each side of the case may present new evidence
c. a judge can overturn a lower court's ruling

problem.question: Which of the following lists is in the correct order from left to right?

choice.feedback: Yes! In the federal court system, a case would first to a U.S. District Court, then a U.S. Court of Appeals, then the U.S. Supreme Court. Note that very few cases actually reach the U.S. Supreme Court.

problem.choice: a. U.S. District Court, U.S. Court of Appeals, U.S. Supreme Court
b. U.S. Court of Appeals, U.S. District Court, U.S. Supreme Court
c. U.S. Supreme Court, U.S. Court of Appeals, U.S. District Court

problem.question: Which of the following usually determines the verdict in a U.S. District Court?
problem.choice: a. judge

choice.feedback: Yes! Juries usually hear cases and determine verdicts in U.S. District Courts.

problem.choice: b. jury
c. justice

problem.question: If the case fails in this court, either side may appeal the verdict to
problem.choice: a. a different U.S. District Court
b. the U.S. Court of Appeals

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Supreme Court could elect to review the case.

problem.choice: c. the U.S. Supreme Court

problem.question: If the events of the case happened in Texas, the people will appeal the case to a U.S. Court of Appeals for the
problem.choice: a. Texas Circuit
b. Washington, D.C. Circuit
c. 5th Circuit

problem.question: Which of the following cases could a U.S. Court of Appeals select to hear?
problem.choice: a. citizen who challenges the verdict of a state trial court
b. citizen who challenges the verdict of the U.S. Supreme Court

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Court of Appeals can review select cases from a federal trial court, called a U.S. District Court.

problem.choice: c. citizen who challenges the verdict of a federal trial court

problem.question: A U.S. District Court is a type of

choice.feedback: Yes! A U.S. Court of Appeals is a type of appellate court. These courts will review select cases from U.S. District Courts.

problem.choice: a. appellate court
b. trial court
c. supreme court

problem.question: If the U.S. Court of Appeals affirms a case, that means that

choice.feedback: Yes! If a U.S. Court of Appeals affirms a verdict, it is saying that the decision of the lower court is correct and will remain in place.

problem.choice: a. the verdict of the lower court will remain
b. the verdict of the lower court is reversed
c. the verdict of the lower court is unclear and needs a new trial

problem.question: The U.S. District Court is the lowest level of federal court where
problem.choice: a. a civil case may be brought to trial
b. each side of the case may present new evidence

choice.feedback: Yes! U.S. Courts of Appeal may overturn a ruling of a U.S. District Court in both criminal and civil cases. The judges will not hear new evidence, however.

problem.choice: c. a judge can overturn a lower courtÕs ruling

problem.question: Which of the following lists is in the correct order from left to right?
problem.choice: a. appeal, trial, verdict

choice.feedback: Yes! First, the case would go to trial and receive a verdict. Either side of the case may appeal the verdict.

problem.choice: b. trial, verdict, appeal
c. verdict, appeal, trial

problem.question: Which of the following usually determines the verdict in a U.S. Court of Appeals?

choice.feedback: Yes! A panel of three judges usually hears cases and determines verdicts in a U.S. Court of Appeals.

problem.choice: a. panel of judges
b. jury members
c. citizen panel

problem.question: If the case fails in this court,

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Supreme Court is the highest court in the U.S. court system.

problem.choice: a. the case is over
b. the state will begin a new trial
c. the justices create a new law

problem.question: Which court has the final authority over all other U.S. courts?
problem.choice: a. a stateÕs supreme court
b. a municipal supreme court

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Supreme Court has final authority over all other courts in the nation.

problem.choice: c. the U.S. Supreme Court

problem.question: The U.S. Constitution created the
problem.choice: a. State-level courts

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Constitution created only the U.S. Supreme Court. Yet it does also protect the right of states to create their own court systems.

problem.choice: b. U.S. Supreme Court
c. U.S. District Court

problem.question: When a case goes to the U.S. Supreme Court
problem.choice: a. all of the original witnesses must appear
b. the president will issue the majority opinion

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Supreme Court will only review evidence from the prior trials, not new information.

problem.choice: c. no new evidence is allowed

problem.question: If a law is labeled 'unconstitutional,' that means that the U.S. Supreme Court

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Supreme Court determines whether laws violate the U.S. Constitution.

problem.choice: a. decided that a state or federal law goes against the U.S. Constitution
b. supports a law even though it does not appear in the U.S. Constitution
c. will rewrite a law so that everyone can agree to it

problem.question: When the U.S. Supreme Court presents the majority opinion,
problem.choice: a. all nine justices must agree to what it says

choice.feedback: Yes! The final ruling, or majority opinion, only requires a majority of justices to agree to it. Justices who disagree present a dissenting opinion.

problem.choice: b. a justice who disagree s presents a dissenting opinion
c. the justices declare that a law is unconstitutional

problem.question: Which of the following could be the last court to hear a case before it arrives at the U.S. Supreme Court?
problem.choice: a. U.S. District Court
b. U.S. Municipal Court

choice.feedback: Yes! The U.S. Supreme Court hears select cases drawn from the U.S. Court of Appeals and state-level supreme courts.

problem.choice: c. U.S. Court of Appeals

problem.question: Which of the following cases is the U.S. Supreme Court most likely to hear?
problem.choice: a. Citizens sue their neighbor for property damage
b. a state prosecutes suspects in a murder trial

choice.feedback: Yes! A case where the constitutionality of a law is in question is most likely case from this group to get to the U.S. Supreme Court.

problem.choice: c. citizens complain that a law in their home state violates their rights

floors.floor: U.S. Supreme Court - highest court in the United States - only court created by the U.S. Constitution - reviews select cases from a U.S. Court of Appeals or a state-level supreme court - hears no new evidence - usually a case gets to this level because the constitutionality of a law is in question - 9 justices - court issues a majority opinion (verdict of the majority of justices) - majority opinion can affirm the constitutionality of a law or declare it unconstitutional - justices who do not vote with the majority issue a dissenting, or minority, opinion to explain why they disagree

U.S. District Court - first court to hear a federal case - can have a jury hear the case - criminal and civil cases - each side presents evidence to prove their argument - 94 districts organized into 12 circuits - at least one U.S. District Court in each state

U.S. Court of Appeals - reviews select cases from a U.S. District Court - usually a 3-judge panel hears the case - no new evidence presented - at least one U.S. Court of Appeals in each of the 12 circuits - court can affirm the lower court decision ("let it stand"), reverse the verdict, or send the case back to the lower court

U.S. Supreme Court - highest court in the United States - only court created by the U.S. Constitution - reviews select cases from a U.S. Court of Appeals or a state-level supreme court - hears no new evidence - usually a case gets to this level because the constitutionality of a law is in question - 9 justices - court issues a majority opinion (verdict of the majority of justices) - majority opinion can affirm the constitutionality of a law or declare it unconstitutional - justices who do not vote with the majority issue a dissenting, or minority, opinion to explain why they disagree
